Who can tell the weight of all theſe fearful Curſes which God hath in his righteous Law, declared againſt thoſe that are under the Guilt o • Sin? ask thoſe that have felt it, under the Terrors of an awakened Conſcience, and they will tell you, that if all the mountains in the World had lain upon them, it could not have been more heavy. It contains in it the Wrath of that God before whom the Devils tremble, whoſe Hand is Omnipotent, a frown of whoſe Countenance is able to diſſol • e the Creation, whoſe Rebuke can blaſt the Creature at once, Pſal. 31.11.

3. If therefore this Guilt abide on you, it will ſink you into perdition. It will be your unavoidable and everlaſting ruine; the fire of the Wrath which is kindled by it, will, if not put out by his grace, burn to the uttermoſt hell: it will never leave till it hath cruſhed you down into the bottomleſs pit; however you may ſeem to ſtout it out for the preſent, you will certainly fall before
it, and a fearful fall it will give you. It will be a •• eadful thing to go out of the World under the Guilt of all that Sin which you are to be charged withal; and when you come to ••• k over into Eternity, as ere long you will, and feel all your Sins lying on you, you would give ten thouſand worlds, if you had them to diſpoſe of, 〈◊〉 be delivered from under the weight of them. Oh that you would ſee and believe it!

1. There is no other way to be diſcharged of this burden. It is only by a pardon that it can 〈◊〉 done, and if you think of any other courſe, 〈◊〉 deceive your ſelves. As long as the Sentence is out againſt you, dooming you to dy, and the Juſtice of God ſtands engaged to the Execution of it, your ſins do and will ly upon you. It is not all your legal repentances, reformations, •• ſtinences from the acts of ſin, that will turn to • y account; you are condemned ſtill, except the Judgment be revoked; and what quiet or comfort can you enjoy as long as it is ſo? ſurely Sin muſt ly heavy, while you are in this condition

2. There is forgiveneſs with him: This is the •• ly relief againſt an accuſing and condemning Conſcience▪ Pſal. 130.3, 4. How this comes to
be, and how wonderfully he hath laid in for it will be hereafter conſidered: but he hath a ſtoc • of forgiveneſs; he can be juſt, and justify, Rom. 3.26. he can abundantly pardon, Iſa. 55.7. and h • alone can do it; there is none elſe in the world that can give you a pardon, but he: if he do not forgive you, if all the men and Angels in the world ſhould do it, it would ſignify nothing a • all.

3. He makes the offer of a pardon to you. He doth not only wait to ſee if you will come and ask it of him, but he ſends to you a Meſſage about it; he hath commanded that you ſhould b • told about it, and pleaded with to accept of it he hath ſent an Embaſſy to you by his Servant who are to entreat you to entertain it, 2 Cor. 20. and he is, all this day of his patience, wai •
ing to ſee whether you will embrace it or no • and why will ye dy? why will you not ſeek 〈◊〉 have your burden thus taken off, but rather chu •• to bear it, though it will overwhelm you in endleſs Deſtruction?

1. There are thoſe that are miſtaken; they find eaſe upon their ſpirits, and they have an hope that their ſins are diſcharged, they would
perſwade themſelves that they have received • emiſſion of them, when there is no ſuch thing: and there are a great many cheats that Satan and their falſe hearts do put on them in this regard, and perſwade them to cry peace to themſelves when there is no peace. You have •• ed then to be very heedful in this reſpect.

2. A miſtake on this account is very perilous. If whiles we pleaſe our ſelves with a dream of pardon, and peace, and quiet our ſelves in it, whiles we are indeed in the gall of bitterneſs, and bond of iniquity, we looſe our opportunity of ſeeking it, are held faſt under our Guilt, and live in hazard every day of dropping into the pit from whence there is no delivery. Let us then take diligent heed on this account, leſt we rue it when too late; and for Rules of Trial.

2. Have you truly gone to God for forgiveneſs? all other attempts are vain and unprofitable; he hath it in his diſpoſal, and will not
put it out of his own hands Jeſus Chriſt, wh • i • God is the diſpe •••• of it, and the invitat •• on is to come to him if we would obtain it. Hav • you ſo done? and if you have, you have relin • quiſhed all other objects of truſt and confidence your former eſſays are no more purſued but re • jected: he hath ſaid that he will be ſought to 〈◊〉 the houſe of Iſrael for this. Have you then hea •• kened to his Call? and ſee that you be not mi • ſtaken in this; it is not every perfunctory pray • er will prove it; it is not every pretended accep •• ing of the offered pardon, that will amount this: there is a ſo coming requiſite. Hence,

3. Have you caſt your ſelves on free grace for it? There is a vaſt difference between a perſo • being acquitted upon a payment, and upon pardon. It may be you have thought you have mourned, repented, forſaken your ſins, and now you have gone in reliance upon theſe for pardon this is a contradiction; a pardon is a free act 〈◊〉 one that hath the power to give it; and if you have gotten it, you went for it, with an alone reliance on that Grace of his, which was revealed to you for your encouragement: you went without money, and without price: You have acknowledged it to be an act of Soveraignty, and accordingly have laid your ſelves down at the footſtool of Soveraign Grace, by an humble reſignation of your ſelves to that; and that hath been all your hope, becauſe he is a pardoning God: you have addreſſed him as David, Pſal. 25.11. For thy name ſake, Oh Lord, pardon mine iniquity.

1. There is a way for you to get eaſe upon this • ccount, a pardon will do it. What though your • ins be not altogether taken away, as to the pre
• ence and activity of them, yet if they may be for
• iven for the preſent, this is good relief in this • uncture; this may ſatisfy your Conſciences, and 〈◊〉 them of their diſtreſs; and will give you aſſurance that the other ſhall be done in due time • oo.

2. There are no Sins ſo great or numerous, but may be thus removed. God is able to take them off, his forgiving Grace and Vertue is not limited; • he vileſt of Sinners may be encouraged to go to • im for it; and if they do, he will in no wiſe • aſt them out: Sins that Lye as mountains between God and you▪ cannot ſtop his way from Coming and pardoning you.

3. It is a good ſign that he intends you a pardon, when he makes you feel your Sins to be an • nſupportable burden. It is the way in which he hath been wont to diſpenſe his Salvation to miſe
• able Sinners. It looks like the beginning towards a good work of Saving Grace▪ the Spirit firſt
Convinceth of ſin, Joh. 16.8. and that conviction will leave oppreſſion upon the Soul: and hen •• the next and immediate invitation of the Goſpel, is to ſuch as are weary and heavy laden under ſuch diſtreſs▪ Mat. 11.28. And for Direction.

1. Beware of flying to other courſes to get eaſe▪ there are many, and we are apt to be tempte • to them: Cains's courſe, Judas's courſe; 〈◊〉 the common courſe of the moſt, in ſeeking 〈◊〉 repair all by legal repentance and amendment,
〈◊〉 deceive you, and you ſhall find it labour 〈◊〉 vain.

2. Be ſure to ſeek a pardon in Gods wa •
▪ As none can give it but he, ſo there is a wa • in which he derives it to us, and you muſt o •• ſerve it; and attend upon it, if you would 〈◊〉 be deceived; and here,

1. Go to him with your Sins; there is a gre •• do that many make, they would go, but they 〈◊〉 ſo vile, and ſo unworthy, and hence th •• would get rid of their ſins firſt: but this wi •• never be; if ever your ſins be taken away,
〈◊〉 muſt do it, Hoſ. 14.2. and the firſt thing he doth in it, is to pardon them, on which th • purging of them follows in order of nature▪ carry all with you, for all want a pardon.

2. Confeſs and bewail them before him; th •• is the way to obtain mercy at his hands, Prov. 2▪ 13. lay them all open before him, with all the •• aggravations to the utmoſt that you can. Th •• is the thing which God expects, and you mu •• not be ſhort in it, but as full as you can. Ta ••
them upon your ſelves, and he will be ready to take them off.

3. Cry to him for Forgiveneſs; this ſhould be the firſt great cry of a guilty Sinner, that God would take off that Guilt: and cry as thoſe that are oppreſſed; let them be loud, earneſt, importunate, inceſſant cries; ſay as he did when he was ſinking, Help, Lord, I periſh. God expects that your prayers be ſenſible ones.

4. Now caſt your burden upon him by Faith; throw your Sins upon his mercy, by laying hold on the Lord Jeſus Chriſt, and his Righteouſneſs. It is the advice, Pſal. 55.22. Caſt thy burden on the Lord; all burdens, none excepted, are here intended; and if this be the greateſt of all, be ſure to roll it on him; and if you do, you ſhall find his helping hand afforded to take it off, and give you reſt.

div.head: Forgiveneſs Covereth Sin. DOCTRINE IV.
div.p:
FOrgiveneſs caſts a Cover over the Sins of him that is pardoned. This is the ſecond expreſſion by which this great benefit is ſet forth, the word a • was obſerved, ſignifies, To hide a thing out of ſight, 〈◊〉 throwing of ſome other thing over it, as we would 〈◊〉 by ſome naſty odious thing, which we would
not have ſeen. 〈◊〉 the clearing up of this Doctrine, we may enquire,
1. What is implied in the Covering of Sin?
2. Who it is that Covers it?
3 How or after what manner it is Covered?
4. What advantage 〈◊〉 to the perſon by having his Sin Covered?
1. What is implied 〈◊〉 Covering of Sin?

A. This phraſe is 〈◊〉 uſed to expreſs the Forgiveneſs of Sin, and is accordingly to be interpreted. Now the reaſon why things are Covered, is that they may be hidden out of ſight; that they may not always be in our eye and view to be looked on; and the end of our Covering a thing is either with reſpect to our ſelves or others. In regard to others, we Cover it, that they may not ſee or know it, thus, 1 Pet. 4.8. Charity ſhall cover the multitude of ſins; i. e. it keeps them to it ſelf, and doth not divulge them. Covering is oppoſed to diſcovering; thus when men bring pretences to put off things, they are ſaid to cover them: excuſes are called Covers. With reſpect to our ſelves we are ſaid to cover a thing, when we put it out of our ſight, in order to the putting it out of our remembrance: and we are wont to do ſo by things, the ſight and memory whereof would be a grief or a vexation to us; and thus are we here to underſtand it. God covers his peoples ſins from his own ſight, that ſo he may not remember them, nor be angry at his Children by reaſon of them, ſo as to take vengeance on them upon the account thereof, the Scripture repreſents Sin as a thing
odious to God, a thing that he cannot endure to look upon, Hab. 1.13. a thing that horribly provokes him againſt the Sinner; and therefore called the abominable thing that he hates, Jer. 44.4. Hence, when he is reſolved to puniſh men for it, he is ſaid, to ſet it in his ſight, Pſal. 90.8 to make ſtrict ſearch after it, Zech. 1.12. To call it to remembrance, Ezek. 21.23. When therefore he comes to pardon it, it ſets it forth by contrary expreſſions, the putting it away, 2 Sam. 12.13. Hiding his face from beholding it, Pſal. 51.9 not ſeeing it, Numb. 23.21. The removing it far from him, Pſal. 103 12. Forgetting, or not remembring it any more, Iſa. 43.25. Caſting it into the depth of the Sea, Mic. 7.19. All of which expreſſions are of the ſame import with this of Covering them.

If it be here enquired, how can God be ſaid to cover our Sin out of his ſight? It muſt be replied, that it is ſpoken after the manner of men, who are wont to forget, or take no notice of that which is laid out of the way. And here let us obſerve.

1. That nothing can be covered to God in reſpect of his Omniſcience. Heb. 4.13. There is no ſuch veil of darkneſs can be caſt over any thing that can intercept his ſight, Pſal. 139.11, 12. Gods Infinite Omnipreſence neceſſarily infers that every thing muſt be in his eye, and it is impoſſible to abſcond it from him, ſo as he ſhall not know it thoroughly; and equally impoſſible that he ſhould forget it; we are on this account often warned to be cautious, becauſe we are ever
under the inſpection of his all ſeeing eye.

2. That God doth not ſo put their Sins out of his ſight, but that he puts them in mind of them, and ſometimes makes them ſmart for them; thus we have Job awfully complaining, Job 13.26. What a ſolemn memorial did he cauſe the Prophet to mention to David? 2 Sam. 12.7, 8. and how much and how long did he make him to ſmart on this account afterwards? yea doutleſs all the Afflictions that are brought on the Children of God in way of Correction for their Sins, are witneſſes that he hath an eye upon them, or a remembrance of them in a diſciplinary way; Hence,
3. This covering them properly reſpects Vindictive Juſtice, or the Sentence of the Law which is out againſt them; and that is the Guilt that cleaves to them, and it is a pardon that doth it▪ For,
1. When God pardons Sin, he removes the Guilt of it from the Sinner; the obligation that lay on him, binding him over to dy, ceaſeth: this hath been already made evident.

2. In removing this Guilt, God turns away his Vindictive eye from it: though the Sin remains, and the merit too, yet God will no longer look on him as a Guilty Sinner; he will not ſee iniquity in him; the man deſerves that he ſhould; but God is reſolved that he will overlook it, as a thing out of ſight; he hath nothing to lay to the man • charge, nor will he hear of any Charge laid againſt him, Rom. 8.33. and this is aptly expreſt by his
covering it, for if he ſhould mark, who could ſtand? Pſal. 130.3.

3. Hereupon the Guilt comes to be utterly loſt; it is a ſtrange expreſſion, Jer. 50 20. The Iniquity of Iſrael ſhall be ſought for▪ and there ſhall be none, and the Sins of Judab, and they ſhall not be found; alas! if ſearch be made, there is enough to be found, that hath been ſinful and provoking; but it refers to puniſhment, which preſumeth Guilt, and ſo there ſhall be none found. When they are put on trial for their lives, and enquiry is made, What Sins are to be charged on ſuch? the anſwer is, there are none to be found, they ſtand condemned for none: and why? for they are cast into the Sea; they are all blotted out of the book of accounts; the Indictment againſt them is defaced; they are covered as a thing that is buried out of ſight, as one that is dead and forgotten; they are blotted out as a Cloud, Iſa. 44 22. and one well obſerves, that a Cloud is it ſelf a blot in the face of the Sky, and is therefore blotted out by making it to vaniſh and diſappear: and ſo doth God by his peoples ſins: and this is the covering of them.
2 Who is it that Covers it?

A. It is God, and he only, who can thus Cover Sin. If Covering be forgiving, then it belongs to him alone who can forgive, and that is Gods Prerogative, Dan. 9.9. If it be the Guilt of Sin that is covered, and ſo covered that it ſhall never riſe again, or be charged, it muſt needs be a Divine Work. Sin is a Tranſgreſſion of Gods Law, and the
Guilt contracted by it is an Obligation to ſuffer accordingly; and who ſhall remove it but he? Men may forgive the wrong that is done to them, ſo far as they are concerned, but they cannot forgive the Violation of the Command of God that is therein perpetrated. Men may indeed Charitatively, or Miniſterially declare this forgiveneſs, but they cannot beſtow it. It is one of the Letters of Gods Name, Exod. 34.7. Forgiving iniquity, Tranſgreſſion and Sin. We may indeed cover the Sins of our Neighbour, by keeping them Secret, and not divulging them, but that doth not hide them from the Revenging Juſtice of God, who will for all in due time make a diſcovery of them, if they be not forgiven by him. And we may cover our own Sins, by denying them, diſſembling, excuſing, extenuating, juſtifying them: but this will but aggravate the Guilt of them, and expoſe us to the more ſevere puniſhment, Prov. 28.13 This covering of Sin belongs to Juſtification; & it is God alone that Juſtifyeth, Rom. 8.33. And indeed God, and no other, hath that cover to throw over the Sins of his people, that can hide them from his revenging eye: Every other cover is but an hiding place of deceit. God therefore challengeth it to himſelf as his prerogative, Iſa. 43.25. I, even I am he that blotteth out thy tranſgreſſions. If all the power and authority in the World, Civil and Eccleſiaſtical, ſhould Subſcribe and Seal an act of Oblivion for us, it will ſignify nothing; no, though the Angels of Heaven ſhould joyn in it. God is Judge of the World, and he can either ratify or
nullify all that is done; his act alone can make it authentick. Hence, though we are to ask forgiveneſs one of another, yet we are not to reſt in that, but if we would have our Sins buried, and not digged up again, we muſt go to him to do it for us.
3. How, or after what manner it is Covered?

A. We are here to conſider God as a Righteous Judge, and therefore to do nothing but what is conſiſtent with that Righteouſneſs of his. We read, Rom. 3.26. He is both juſt, and juſtifyeth. Now it is one piece of Gods Righteouſneſs as a Judge, to puniſh the Sinner according to Law; and Guilt binds him over to puniſhment: how then doth he continue juſt, and yet cover this Guilt ſo as it ſhall not riſe againſt the Sinner to procure his puniſhment? And the reſolution of it is in Sum; That he doth it by caſting the Robe of Chriſts Righteouſneſs over the Sinner, and ſo covering his Sin out of his ſight. And here two things offer themſelves to conſideration,
1. That the Righteouſneſs of Chriſt is a Robe ſuitable and ſufficient to cover our Sins.
2. How God caſts it over us to this purpoſe?

1. That the Righteouſneſs of Chriſt is a Robe ſufficient and ſuitable to cover our Sins. As Sin is compared in Scripture to our Nakedneſs and Shame, ſo is Chriſts Righteouſneſs reſembled by a Robe provided to cover it withal: and as it was Sin that firſt gave occaſion for mans needing ſomething to cover his Body, ſo it introduceth the neceſſity of Chriſt to hide the nakedneſs and filthineſs of our
Souls. This is deſigned by the beſt Robe, Luk. 15.22. This is pointed at in the White Raiment, Rev. 3.18. And this is the Wedding Garment, Matth. 22.11. Now this Robe is made of the Active and Paſſive Obedience of Chriſt, for the matter of it. By the former of theſe he kept the Law exactly, Fulfilling all Righteouſneſs, Matth. 3.15. He was Holy, Harmleſs, Undefiled, and without Spot. By the latter he made full ſatisfaction to the Law in all its demands, by bearing the whole penalty that was threatned in it for Sin. And the ſufficiency of this Garment to cover all the Guilt of our Sin herein appears.

1. This Righteouſneſs it ſelf anſwered the Law in the utmoſt extent of it; ſo that it is wide enough and large enough to cover all Guilt. Chriſt bare the penalty to the full which the Law exacted; he bare the whole weight of that wrath which was due to man for Sin. His Righteouſneſs therefore is able to hide the greateſt and moſt multiplied tranſgreſſions out of ſight: the Law can ask no more than there is in that, to anſwer God as a Judge, who is fully pleaſed with the Righteouſneſs of Chriſt.

2. There is enough in it to Cloath all that come to him for it. It is called Everlaſting Righteouſneſs, Dan. 9.24. becauſe it will hold out as far as there is occaſion for it: there may be Garments cut out of it for as many as ask for them, and to ſpare: it can never have an end: the Vertue of Chriſts ſatisfaction is Infinite, Heb. 7.25. All are therefore invited to come for it, and a promiſe is made that
none that do come ſhall be rejected. It is called the Righteouſneſs of God, Phil. 3.9. becauſe the perſon whoſe it was, or who performed it, was God, and ſo put a Divine Vertue into it, making it infinitely extenſive.

3. This Righteouſneſs was provided on purpoſe for this end; it was prepared to cover the Guilt of Sin. As the Active Obedience of Chriſt was to purchaſe for us the inheritance, ſo his Paſſive was to ſatisfy Revenging Juſtice on our account, by Vertue whereof our Guilt comes to be hidden out of it's ſight, by the caſting of this over it. Jeſus Chriſt neither Lived for himſelf, nor Dyed for himſelf. The Son of God needed no Active Obedience to Juſtify him, being a Perſon above Law; nor did Chriſt need a Paſſive Obedience to ſatisfy for himſelf, as man, being perfectly righteous: He therefore Gave himſelf for us, Gal. 2.20. And this was according to Divine compact, ſo that it is the deſign of it, and it was laid in for this; and thus it becomes applicable to us, and ſo is every way ſufficient.
2. How God caſts it over us to this purpoſe?
A. He doth it by applying this Righteouſneſs to us for our Juſtification: which is fitly expreſt by his Clothing us with it to hide our Sin out of his ſight; for in this application,

1. God having accepted of this Righteouſneſs for us, looketh upon it as ours. For this reaſon Chriſt is called, The Lord our Righteouſneſs, Jer. 23.6. And ſaid to be made Righteouſneſs to us, 1 Cor.
• .30. And this is a reſult from the Everlaſting
C ••• rivance of it in the Covenant of Suretiſhip, i •
〈◊〉 the Father promiſed to him this reward, 〈◊〉 is Obedience ſhould redound to the Juſtifi
••• ion of many, Iſa 53.11. i. e. As many as it wa •
〈◊〉 be applied unto.

2. Hence in the act of Juſtification he confers this Righteouſneſs upon us to be ours. Having already accepted it for us, he now beſtows it upon us; it firſt was made ready, and then it is put on▪ So that it is not ours Inherently, but Adherently, o •
Relatively, it is, in reſpect to us, not a perſonal bu • a relative Righteouſneſs; and in that regard fitly reſembled to a Garment, which is no part of the man, but yet it is his, and put upon him for a covering.

3. In conferring this Righteouſneſs upon us, he Cloaths us with it. He throws it over us, ſo that we who were before naked, are now arrayed with it, ſo that all our defects and deformities are hidden under it: hence the Apoſtles expreſſion of being found in it, Phil. 3.9. And it covers us all over, ſo that whatever faults are in us, they are thus put out of ſight.

4. Hereupon he judgeth of us by and according to this Righteouſneſs. He looks no farther, as a Judge than to this: by it therefore we are made the Righteouſneſs of God, 2 Cor. 5.21. We are now, on a relative account, pure, and clear, and ſpotleſs; Juſtice hath nothing to lay to our charge, becauſe we, having put on Christ the Righteous, are Righteous in him.
4. What advantage accrues to the perſon by having his Sins thus covered?
A. Much every way: in particular,

1. He is, in the Law account, as if he had never Sinned. For, whatever he hath been and 〈◊〉 the Law hath nothing to accuſe him of; 〈◊〉 which cannot be proved, is in the Laws account a • if it were not, and that which is hidden cannot be proved: when once Sin is covered, there is none to accuſe us, for if God will not, who ſhall? if he hath nothing to charge on us, we are ſafe: but he ſaith, I ſee no Iniquity in the perſon.

2. Hence he is out of the danger of Condemnation. Rom 8.1, 34. Condemnation is properly a Sentence paſt by the Judge, upon a perſon Convicted to be Guilty, dooming him to ſuffer penalty according to the mind of the Law: So that where there is no Guilt, there can be no Condemnation; and where there is no Tranſgreſſion chargable, there can be no Guilt found.

3. Hence flows great Peace of Conſcience. It is the foundation on which our deliverance from the terrours of an accuſing Conſcience is built: when that tells us we have thus and ſo Sinned, & thereby provoked God, it is hereby pacified, when it can look on all this Sin as covered. Now the Spirit of Bondage, which is rooted in every unpardoned Sinner, is remedied, Rom. 8.15. The Soul hath the ground of inward Tranquillity notwithſtanding all; and hereupon he can, with the more humbling ſenſe, mourn for his Sin, whiles he can mourn as one that hath a good hope, and is not ſunk in deſpondency.

4. He hath great liberty of acceſs with boldneſs to the Throne of Grace; there is ſuch a liberty which Gods Children enjoy, Heb. 4.16. and this is that which principally contributes to it. It is ſin that makes us afraid. When our firſt Parents were naked, they hid themſelves, Gen. 3 8. but now being thus cloathed, their ſhame and fear is taken away. When we know that our ſin is covered, we need not be terrified with the thoughts of the Holineſs and Righteouſneſs of God.

5. Hence he ſhall with greateſt comfort appear before the Judgement Seat of Chriſt in the great Day? and this is a priviledge beyond concep ••
on. What is it that makes Sinners afraid of that terrible day, but their Sins, the Guilt whereof makes them fearfully to expect the Vengeance of it? when therefore theſe are covered, that danger is removed, and ſo they can ſtand upright then; they may hold up their heads with joy, who have theſe Garments of Salvation thrown over them.
USE I. Learn we hence the miſerable ſtate of all Unpardoned Sinners. If this benefit belong only to the pardoned, then ſurely thoſe that have not gotten into this ſtate are very unhappy; for,

1. All their ſins ly open and naked to the eye of Gods Vindictive Juſtice. We read, Hab. 1.13. That he is of purer eyes, &c. but now all their ſins are in his view; they are uncovered; not only Gods all ſeeing eye diſcerns them, but his revengful eye looks upon them; they are caſt out naked to
the loathing of their perſons; God cannot look upon them without indignation, he deſpiſeth their Image: Sin is the abominable thing that he hates; and their ſin lies before him, and he muſt hate it. God ſaith of all their ſins, as in Jer. 29.23. I know, and am a witneſs.

2. Hence when they are judged, they muſt needs be condemned; this follows upon the conſideration of Gods Holineſs and Relative Juſtice. God ſtands engaged to paſs Sentence upon every one as they ſtand related to his Holy Law: if he ſees Sin in men, and upon trial they are found Guilty, they are condemned already, and the Judge of all the earth will do that which is right; it is therefore impoſſible that they, in ſuch a condition, ſhould eſcape his righteous Judgement, for we read, Rom. 2.6. He will render to every man according to his deeds.

3. Hence the whole weight of Gods Wrath will certainly fall upon them at laſt; they cannot eſcape it; if he paſs the Sentence on them, he will puniſh them, for that is paſt in order to Execution. Our Saviour tells us what ſhall be the iſſue of the Sentence of the Great Day, Mat. 25. ult. and who knows the forlorn condition of that man, who muſt thus fall into the hands of the living God? it had been good for that man if he had never been born. Eternal Separation from the preſence of Gods favour, with an endleſs ſuffering the Torments of Hell, are his portion from the hand of God; and how dreadful a thing is this?
USE II. Let it ſerve to awaken and encourage Sinners to ſeek to God for this priviledge. This Doctrine will ſerve to both theſe ends, and let me urge it in both reſpects.

1. Conſider, you are all of you by Sin become Guilty before God; all the world by nature are in this condition, Rom. 3.19. Whatever other difference the Goſpel priviledges have made between ſome and others, which are great, and are not to be deſpiſed, but prized; yet herein all are alike. There is never a Child of Adam can excuſe himſelf from Sin; and Guilt is an inſeparable concomitant of Sin, according to the Law under which you are; that hath ſaid, Ezek 18.4. The Soul that Sins, that Soul ſhall dy; and there is no man, whiles under the Law, that can exemp • himſelf from it.

2. Hence except your ſins are covered, you are undone; if Sin riſe up and appear againſt you, when you come to your trial, it will procure that Condemnation which will ruine you for ever, read the Sentence, and that will be enough to convince you of this, Mat. 25.34. Depart ye Curſed, &c. and is not he an undone man on whom this muſt paſs? for as ſure as you are Creatures, ſo certainly will it be executed, if once it proceed from the mouth of the Judge againſt you.

3. There is no other way but this to have your Sin covered; you may ſeek to cover it out of ſight by your ſecrecy, but you cannot ſo put
a blind upon the all ſeeing eve • You may endeavour to cover it with • ooliſh pretences and excuſes, but he with whom you have to do is not ſo to be impoſed upon; or you may think to hide it under a Repentance and Righteouſneſs of • our own, but the Covering will be too ſhort and too narrow; there is nothing but this Robe that can hide it out of Gods ſight; Paul therefore was afraid of being found in his own righteouſneſs, Phil. 3.9.

4. There is yet an opportunity to obtain this. God ha •• provided this Garment, and makes offer of it to Sinners in the day of his patience and grace; and ſaith, if they will accept of it, he will beſtow it upon, and put it on them; this is the great buſineſs of the Goſpel treaty, in which God by the means, perſwades with men to ſee their •• ed of it, and the ſufficiency there is in it, that they may be willing to accept of it. Jeſus Chriſt will have Sinner • to put him on, that their nakedneſs may not be ſeen, Rev. 3.18.

5. When your Sin is thus coverd, God can be both juſt and forgive you; the Righteouſneſs of God is not baulked, but honoured in this way, 1 Joh. 1.9. you may ſay, how can the Juſtice of the Law conſiſt with the forgiveneſs of my ſins? it is anſwered, and it is enough, they are covered with the Robe of Chriſt's Righteouſneſs; God hath accepted that on your ſcore Chriſt, in his Humiliation was under the imputation of Sin, and Gods Juſtice took its ſatisfaction of him for you, for he was made Sin for us, 2 Cor. 5.21.
And now his Righteouſneſs becomes yours, the Law is ſatisfied, and your ſins hidden under that Satisfaction! Be then perſwaded of your need and be not diſcouraged ſince he calls you. here,

1. Be ſure to renounce your own Righteouſneſs if you are reſolved to have that for your cover▪ Chriſt will not afford you his. Paul plainly intimates the inconſiſtency of theſe, in Phil. 3 9 and tells us this was the reaſon why the Jews miſt of Gods Righteouſneſs, Rom 10.3. Say then that your beſt are filthy rags, Iſa. 64.6. reſolve that your moſt ſpecious actions are unprofitable on the account of your Juſtification, and that you are naked without this Robe.

2. Be ſure then to get under the covert of the Righteouſneſs of Chriſt by Faith; 〈◊〉 God doth give us this Garment, of his Grace,
〈◊〉 apply it to us by his Spirit, ſo we are to put it on by believing. When we take hold on Chriſt by believing, we ſo get under his Shadow, and his Righteouſneſs cloaths us; this then is your great buſineſs, to believe on him; ſo will his Righteouſneſs become yours, and then you are cloathed.
USE III. Here is ground of Conſolation to the Children of God, under the deepeſt ſenſe of their own Sins: And here,

1. This ſhould not hinder, but further your humbling ſenſe of them though God doth not look on them, you ſhould. Soul abaſement for Sin, and mourning by reaſon of it, belong to
that Sanctification which we are all to purſue, if ſin be not made vile, and abaſing to us, by the apprehenſion of a pardon, we may queſtion whether we do rightly apprehend it.

2. But yet it ſhould comfort your hearts under this ſenſe. Conviction of ſin and Guilt joyned together will raiſe horrors in the Conſcience; whereas Conviction of ſin, and apprehenſion of a pardon, together with making us more vile in our own eyes, will afford a ſupport to us, and as the one humbleth us, ſo the other relieves us, and gives us matter of conſolation; for,

1. Chriſt having caſt his skirt over you, your Sins are now for ever covered. When this Garment is thrown on us, it is never pluckt off again; it is one of thoſe Gifts of God that are without Repentance •
your Sins are now Sunk, and can riſe up no more, they are hidden, and cannot be found again, though they ſhould be ſought for.

2. Hereupon his whole Righteouſneſs appears in the ſight of God for you. When God looks upon you in him, he ſees all the perfect Obedience of Chriſt as yours, and it is in the Law account as much as if you had perſonally performed it; for you are accepted in the Beloved, Eph. 1.6 So that the vertue and efficacy of that Righteouſneſs muſt needs derive to you.

3. Hence your eſtate ſhall be determined for ever according to that Righteouſneſs; the Judgment will paſs upon that ſcore, and how happy are you then? for if Chriſt hath by it ſatisfied the Law for Sin, in bearing the penalties, and
purchaſed the promiſed rewards by fulfilling all its precepts, all this ſhall be yours, and you muſt needs be happy.

div.head: Pardon conſiſts in the Non-Imputation of Sin. DOCTRINE V.
div.p: PArdon conſists properly in the Non Imputation, 〈◊〉 the taking off the Imputation of Sin. This is the third expreſſion in our Text, by which this forgiveneſs is illuſtrated, viz. Sin is not imputed; and there are two things go in to make this Non-Imputation to amount to a pardon.
1. The man was under Guilt before this 〈◊〉 paſt upon him. When Sin is not Imputable, the Non-Imputation of it is not forgiveneſs, for 〈◊〉 had nothing to be forgiven him, being a righteous perſon.
2. That this Guilt be taken off, that he cea • to be a Guilty perſon in the account of the Law, and of the Judge. Hence then we may for the clearing up of this Truth, enquire,
1. What is meant by the Imputation of Sin?
2. In what reſpect all mankind are by nature under this Imputation?
3. What is the ſtate of thoſe who are under th •• Imputation?
4. How this Imputation comes to be taken off from ſinful men?
1. What is meant by the Imputation of ſin?

A. We obſerved, that the word in our Text is often uſed for reckoning, or charging to ones account, or making a man a debtor for a thing. Man is by ſin become a Debtor to the Juſtice of God, and that expects ſatisfaction of him, and accordingly chargeth it to his ſcore, that it may call him to an account about it: hence in the Imputation of ſin; there are theſe things to be conſidered.

1. That Sin is reckoned to the perſon. Here lies the foundation of it, and hence it is called the Imputation of Sin, becauſe all that follows, flows from it; and hence it is to be obſerved, that this Imputation being a Forenſical act, if the Sin may any way be faſtned on the man as his, ſo that he ſtands related to it as his own, whether he himſelf hath actually committed it or no, yet it is juſtly imputed to him: David did not with his own hand ſlay Uriah, but yet the Sin is made his, 2 Sam. 12.9. ſo, if a man owes nothing on a Debt firſtly contracted by him, yet if he owes it by Suretiſhip, it is legally imputed to him.

2. Hence the Guilt of it is charged upon him; and indeed, theſe two are inſeparable in the Law; for looking upon the man as under it, it is impoſſible that he ſhould be charged with Sin, but he muſt be reputed Guilty by it: that hath connected the prohibition and the threatning inſeparably; it hath ſaid, He that Sins ſhall dy; and it cannot go back from it. Now the Charge of Guilt is nothing elſe but the aſſuring of the man,
that he is by Sin become a Subject of Death; ſo ſaith the Law, Ezek. 18 4. and a righteous God looks upon ſuch a man, and reckons him bound over to dy.

3. Hereupon the Law rigorouſly demands its ſatisfaction of him; the Law is ratified by the Law-giver, and he will give it its claim, and is reſolved that it ſhall not ſuffer loſs in a tittle, Mat. 5.28. It ſaith, I find this man to be under the charge of ſin, and ſo to be Guilty, and I demand Juſtice upon him: and its mouth cannot be ſtopt till it hath its demands anſwered: it is reſolved it will have its penniworths out of the perſon, before it hath done with him.

4. Hereby he is obnoxious to ſuffer all the penalties of the Law, in purſuit of this charge; thu • Imputation makes him a priſoner of Juſtice, and liable to the execution of the threatning: hence ſaid to be in danger, Mat. 5.22. the word ſignifieth, one that is held in, and kept faſt, as one that is impriſoned: this execution being the deſign of, and that in which the Imputation is to determine. Imputation claps an arreſt upon the man, which will be proſecuted, till Juſtice hath obtained all its demands of him.
2. In what reſpect all mankind by nature are under this Imputation?

A. That all are ſo, is every where aſſerted in Scripture; and is evident, becauſe the penalties properly belonging to ſin are fallen upon them all▪ See Rom. 5.12.14. 1 Cor. 15.22. If all are Sinners, then ſin is imputable to all, and if they are
dead by it, it hath ſurely been imputed. Certainly that Sin which hath killed a whole world, is imputed to them, how elſe had they died by it? it includes old and young, perſons of underſtanding, and Infants, whoſoever deſcends from Adam by natural generation, and hath a reaſonable Soul. Now there is a threefold reſpect in which ſin comes to be imputable to mankind, and that righteouſly.

1. When it is actually and perſonally committed by the man. I name this firſt, becauſe it is moſt plain and accountable. Sin is properly a Moral Tranſgreſſion, and ſuppoſeth a Law againſt which the tranſgreſſion is: and to actual ſin it is requiſite that it be done by a reaſonable creature, capable of acting as a cauſe by counſel: this therefore is not imputable to Infants, for, though they have a reaſonable Soul in them, yet it is not in a preſent capacity of exerciſing that reaſon; which want ſeems not to be a fruit of ſin, but a condition of nature, and had not man fallen, it would in all likelihood have been ſo; it is therefore ſaid of thoſe that dy in their Infancy, That they have not ſinned after the ſimilitude of Adams Tranſgreſſion, Rom. 5.14. Though how ſoon they diſcover their natural corruption is lamentably to be obſerved; however this extends to all men without exception, that arrive to any uſe of their reaſon; how actual ſin will be charged on meer naturals, I cannot graſp, though the want of the uſe of reaſon be a puniſhment of Adams ſin; yet this utterly obſtructs the rational acting of ſuch an one, for
that he cannot diſcern between good and evil. But there is none that ever had the uſe of reaſon, but hath abuſed it by ſinning againſt God, and that both by ſins of Omiſſion and Commiſſion: he hath thought, ſpoken, done otherwiſe than the Law requires; we have a natural man characterized, Rom. 3.10. &c. And none are exempted from it, we are told, Pſal. 58.3. They go aſtray as ſoon as they are born, ſpeaking lies; i. e. they are ſet that way, and it breaks out as ſoon as they are capable, though in ſome more notoriouſly than in others. Now there is no difficulty in telling how actual ſin ſhould be imputable to the perſon committing it; for, if all owe Obedience to the Law, their neglect of, or doing any thing contrary to it, cannot but render them Guilty.

2. When the nature is corrupted by the inherency of Original Sin. That there is ſuch a thing as the ſin of nature is evident from the word of God; it is called Concupiſcence or Luſt, Jam. 1.14. Indwelling Sin; Rom 7.17 Sin that is alwayes preſent. Verſe 21 The Fleſh, Joh. 3.6. The body of ſin. Rom. 6.6. Of Death, 7.24. The Law in the members, v.23. The body of the Sins of the fleſh, Col 2.11. The Old man, Eph. 4.23. Now all theſe point to the root or fountain from which actual Sin proceeds, and therefore muſt intend ſomething divers from it; hence we read of Luſt Conceived, and Sin the iſſue of it, Jam. 1.15. Now this Sin is in all Adams Poſterity, born after the ordinary courſe of nature; even Infants, and Naturals too: it is therefore uſually called Our Birth Sin, and Our Conception Sin,
according to, Pſal 51.5. And it derives from the corrupt fountain from whence we all proceed. Adam defiled himſelf, loſt the Image of God, contracted the Image of Sin, and then he Propagated it, Gen. 5.2. And how ſhould it be otherwiſe? for Who can bring a clean thing cut of an unclean? Job 14.4. And though this be in one ſence a puniſhment fallen upon us for the firſt Tranſgreſſion, yet in it ſelf it is really Sin; it is a Sinful ſtate that we are in by it; the Definition of ſin belongs to it, it is Anomy, 1 Joh. 3.4. Mans nature by it doth not anſwer the Law of Creation And that it is imputed is evident, becauſe it is an Image for which God deſpiſeth man, Pſal. 73.20. It is that which they Dy for, Rom. 5.14. Pſal. 137 ult. It is certainly in them, and therefore may be charged on them, and the Righteouſneſs of their being found Guilty by reaſon of it, will one day be made good by him who is Judge of all: mean while the foundation of the equity of it is laid in that which follows: Hence,

3. In reſpect of the Relation which they bear to Adams firſt Tranſgreſſion That our firſt Parents became Guilty by their eating the forbidden fruit, is beyond diſpute: God had a Sovereign Authority to Command, and they owed him entire Obedience: the Sin it ſelf was great, being a Violation of the Sacrament of the Covenant, and ſo the whole Law was tranſgreſſed by it: and that they dyed juſtly none can rationally doubt. But we are given to underſtand that they drew their whole Poſterity into the ſame Condemnation with
themſelves, and this is clear from, Rom. 5.12, 17, 18, 19. Hence, though they were not actually in being, yet that Sin is imputed to them as theirs, and here upon they ſuffer penally for it: their being born in Sin, and unto miſery is a proper reſultancy from it. Verſe 12. The equity of which Imputation is, in that God tranſacted with Adam at firſt as a Publick Perſon, in whom he would have all to ſtand or fall: he therefore repreſented his whole Progeny, as a King doth his people, as a Father his Family: So that all Humanity being contracted in our firſt Parents, humane nature became Guilty in and with them, as it was naturally derivable from them.
3. What is the state of thoſe that are under this Imputation?

A. In one word, it is a ſtate of Condemnation. We read, Joh. 3.18. He that believes not, is Condemned already: By which we are given to underſtand how it is with all men by nature: all the World ſtand Condemned before God, and there is not one clear of it, till by Faith in Chriſt they come to receive a diſcharge. Now they come under this Condemnation, by the Imputation of Sin to them: for Condemnation hath a reſpect to puniſhment, and that always preſumes a fault that hath merited it: and hence, in a fair proceſs, the fault is firſt charged and proved, and there-upon the Sentence paſſeth. Now this muſt needs be a miſerable ſtate, if we Conſider,

1. That if God impute Sin to any, he will condemn them for it; the Righteouſneſs of God as a
Lawgiver and Judge calls for this. God cannot behold Iniquity in any, without deteſtation of it, Hab. 1.13. And the Sanction of the Law, by which he teſtifyeth this deteſtation of his, is that which he hath bound himſelf unto. As therefore God will charge none but Guilty Sinners, and ſuch as he will convince of Sin and Guilt, ſo he will doom them accordingly, for in this his Relative Juſtice manifeſts it ſelf.

2. That if God do thus condemn, he will proceed to Execution according to it. He will be as good as his Word, and the Condemned Sinner ſhall find it ſo to his coſt. God ſaith as he meaneth, and will therefore do as he faith. When God had paſt a fearful doom upon Saul for his diſobedience, we find what a Seal he clapt upon that Sentence, 1 Sam. 15.29. The ſtrength of Iſrael will not ly or repent. True, there is room at preſent, under the Goſpel, to have the Sentence reverſed by a free pardon; but if this be neglected, and the perſon comes thus to the bar of Juſtice at laſt, he muſt feel the Execution.

3. The puniſhment of Sin is tremendous. It is a fearful thing to fall into the hands of the living God. Heb. 10.31. In this puniſhment God will make it known how hateful a thing to him Sin is, and he will do it by the fearfulneſs of it: hence theſe penalties are ſet forth in the word of God after a formidable manner. God intends in it to ſhew his wrath, and make his power known, Rom. 9.22. Theſe penalties are expreſſed as intolerable, Ezek. 22.14.
4. How this Imputation comes to be taken off from Sinful men?

A. In Sum, it is done by the Tranſlation of it from the account of the Sinner, to the account of Chriſt. There is no other way in which it can be done conſiſtent with the Juſtice of G •• : and in this way it may be, and is done for all that are pardoned. Of this we may take this ſhort account.

1. That whereſoever Sin is Imputed, the Law requires ſatisfaction of the perſon to whom it is Imputed. This is evident by the nature of imputation, according as hath been explained: for where God reckons Sin to a man, he gives the Law Credit againſt him for it, and makes him a Debtor to the Law; now the Law being a Rule of Juſtice, is rigorous, and exacts all its debts: it will not ſtop its mouth, till compleatly ſatisfyed▪ Math. 5.18. So that it holds the man faſt by vertue of this Imputation.

2. That in Chriſts Sufferings there was a ſufficiency to make this ſatisfaction. This was neceſſarily prerequiſite, elſe it could not have anſwered the demand of the Law for us. For, though it be not therefore our Satisfaction, becauſe there was ſuch a ſufficiency in it, Gods acceptance of it being free; yet if it could not have anſwered the Law in all its demands, it could not have been capable of Gods acceptance on this account: there was therefore enough in it to do this. Chriſt Suffered the whole Eſſence of the penalties that were due to us for ſin; he bore the whole weight of the Wrath of God; He was made Sin, 2 Cor. 5.21.
And A Curſe, Gal. 3.13. And the Excellency of his perſon, being Divine, put that Value upon his Sufferings, that rendered them equivalent to the Sufferings of all his people: it 〈◊〉
the blood of God that was ſhed, Act. 20.28.

3. That it is conſiſte •• with Gods Juſtice, to accept of this Satisfaction on the Sinners account. True, the caſe is Criminal; the Sinner himſelf deſerves to dy, and if God had ſaid he ſhall dy, and no other for him, it had been very juſt: but yet it is no wrong either to his Holineſs or Juſtice to ſay, I will accept of the Sufferings of Chriſt for the Sinner. If there were nothing more to be ſaid for this than that God hath actually ſo done, this ought to be enough to ſtop our mouths, for the Judge of the World can do nothing but what is right. But it is acknowledged among men, that a Prince may, if he will, although he may chuſe whether he will take another for the offender by exchange, if he freely offers himſelf: however, God is not bound to the Laws which men are.

4. That God did, by an act of Sovereignty, accept of Chriſt for this end. This is evident in the Revelation of the New Covenant, in which we are told that there was ſuch a thing: and all our hopes for Salvation by that Covenant, are built on this foundation; for we are Saved by Chriſt, we are therefore acquainted with a Covenant of Redemption, on which the New Covenant of Grace is founded; in which God the Father indented with his Son on this account, and made him a promiſe in
reſpect to it, that upon his Satisfaction the Vertue of it ſhould derive to them for whom it was, Iſa. 53.10. And Chriſt dyed for this end, Gal. 2.20. Yea he was made under the Law, that ſo it might exact this of him, in order to our being Redeemed from it, Gal. 4.4, 5. And hence all the penalties he underwent are ſaid to be on the account of Our Sins, Iſa. 53.4. And this acceptance was an act of Divine Sovereignty; God acted as a Lord in it.

5. That Chriſt in theſe Sufferings bare thoſe relations to his Elect, which rendred them ſatisfactory for them; he did all in their ſtead, and that it might be effectual, he took ſuch Relation • that rendred it ſo in the account of Gods Juſtice. Now there were two relations that he bare, which comprize in them all that can be required in this regard.

1. Of a Surety; this is expreſſed, Heb. 7.22 Now a Surety is one that is bound with or for anothe • , to reſpond for him, in caſe he him •••• fails: and when it refers to caſes criminal, he becomes liable to ſuffer for the principal offender, and upon his ſo ſuffering, the Law is ſatisfied, and he for whom he ſuffered is releaſed; for no Law requires double ſatisfaction in the ſame caſe: and therefore if the Law take its ſatisfaction on the Surety, it exempts the offender himſelf; but there is yet more, viz.

2. Of a Common perſon or repreſentative, which will yet be a clearer diſcovery of the fulneſs of the ſatisfaction. We therefore have a parallel
made between Chriſt and Adam, 1 Cor. 15.22. And Adam is ſaid to be a figure of Chriſt, Rom. 5.14. Now Adam ſtood as a publick perſon, repreſenting his Seed; and ſo doth Chriſt repreſent his: hence as Adams tranſgreſſion was influential to the undoing of his Seed, ſo Chriſt's ſatisfaction is no leſs to the making or repairing of his. verſe 18.

6. Hence this pardon of ſin removes our Guilt to Chriſt's account, and his Righteouſneſs to ours: this is fully expreſt, in 2 Cor. 5.21. He was made ſin for us, that we might be made the Righteouſneſs of God through him; i. e. Our ſin was charged on him, and his Satisfaction went for it, and his Righteouſneſs was reckoned to us, and ſo became ours: and this is done by Imputation. Nor can it be in any other way; it muſt be ours either Relatively, or Inherently; Inherently it cannot be, neither can Chriſt be the real Sinner, nor can his Sufferings, which in perſon ſuffered, be ſuffered perſonally by us; but by this tranſaction it becometh ſo by Imputation.

7. This is done upon our believing in Chriſt; they that talk of an Eternal Juſtification, forget to diſtinguiſh between a purpoſe, a purchaſe, and the application of it to us, which are not to be confounded. It was purpoſed from Eternity, ſettled in the Covenant of Suretiſhip; it was purchaſed when Chriſt ſuffered in our ſtead, and confirmed to him in his Reſurrection, Rom. 4.25. but it is conferred on us, and this tranſlation actually made, on our believing in Chriſt, Rom. 3.22, 24. and when
it cometh to this, then ſin is no more imputed to us; and now, and not till now is the man 〈◊〉 pardoned man.
USE I. For Information, in a few particulars

1. Learn hence, that forgiveneſs of ſin is an act of free Grace. It doth not • ay, the man in whom there is no ſin, but to whom God imputes it 〈◊〉 ; it ſuppoſeth that there is ſin, and that God might impute it if he would, and why doth he not? true, it is upon Chriſt's account, ſo that it is not free to him, but purchaſed by him: but in reſpect of us, there is no merit of ours in the caſ • , the Pſalmiſt ſaith, Pſal. 130.3, 4. If thou, Lord, ſhouldeſt mark iniquity, &c. but for Chriſt's ſake he will not ſo do; though the man hath been guilty of never ſo many ſins, yet he will not lay any of them to his charge. Juſtice lets fall its action againſt him, and diſchargeth him from the arreſt that was laid upon him; and this is done through Chriſt, 2 Cor. 5.18. needs th •• muſt it be free grace: Well might the Apoſtle ſay, Rom. 3.24. Juſtified freely by his Grace, through the Redemption that is in Jeſus Chriſt.

2 Hence we have a clear diſcovery of the bleſſedneſs of a pardoned man; well might the Pſalmiſt put that remark upon ſuch an one; for indeed one eſſential part of the miſery of Sinner • is that they are under the Imputation of Sin▪ Whence ariſeth their obnoxiouſneſs to the Fiery Indignation of God, which by this Non-Imputation
they are delivered from; by this the Wrath of God paſſeth from them; and if God will not charge i • , their ſin can never bring them into Condemnation▪ let them have committed never ſo many or gr • at ſins, they can do them no hurt on this account; they are thus put out of all danger of hell, and the miſeries o • that place; and ſurely he is an happy man.

3. Learn hence the neceſſity of Chriſt's paſſive Obedience, in order to our forgiveneſs. If he had not ſuffered, we could not have been pardoned: for ſuch is our relation to the Law of Juſtice, that if once we have contracted Guilt to our ſelves, there is a Law Imputation of it to us: and to the • aking that off again, nothing leſs can be neceſſary than that the Law be anſwered; and that requires ſatisfaction, and will not take up without it. Nor was there any to be found that was able to give in this ſatisfaction for us, but the Son of God in our nature: if he had not done it, no other could; ſo that we muſt have remained under the charge, how then could God have been Juſt, and yet Juſtifie us? Rom. 3.26 to him then are we to acknowledge this wonderful benefit.

4. This tells us that forgiveneſs ſhould not take away, but encreaſe our ſelf loathing. When God cometh to forgive us, he finds us Sinners, elſe we ſhould not need forgiveneſs; and in forgiving he doth not take away the being of the ſin he forgives, or make us inherently righteous, though together with it he ever Sanctifies us; but withdraws the Imputation from it; but ſtill there
is the vileneſs and the odiouſneſs of it lying before us, and it is not leſs odious, becauſe God will not impute it; but the conſideration of this rich favour ſhould make us to abominate it ſo much the more, as it did Paul, Rom. 7.

5. This ſhews us whence the Conſolation of Gods people flows, under the ſenſe of all thei • ſins. What is the reaſon why a Guilty Sinner, under the awakenings of Conſcience, and diſcoveries of Sin, is terrified, and ready to ſink into deſpair, going up and down as one amazed; when a Child of God ſees and knows as much by himſelf, as many and as great ſins that he hath committed, and yet can look upon them, though not without deep ſelf a • aſement, yet with a great deal of conſolation and triumph? Why the one ſees not the ſin only, but the Imputation too whereas this man can ſay, that God doth not impute his ſins, and ſo his Soul is comforted on that account.

6. See here the reaſon why ſuch as have been great Sinners, and are pardoned, do abound in their love to Jeſus Chriſt; there are none that are more carried forth with ardent affections to him, or more engaged to do or ſuffer for him; our Saviour gives the reaſon of it, Luk. 7.47. who ever more engaged in ſetting forth the riches of Grace tha •
ſoul? 1 Tim. 1.15, 16. and why? but becauſe ſuch an one ſees that his debt and forfeiture was very great, he was Ten thouſand Talents in arrears, his ſcore was formidable, but
it is all croſt, there is not one that ſtands on the Account book againſt him.
USE II. Let this be to Exhort us all to ſeek after forgiveneſs; and one would think it ſhould be enough to put us all upon it to ſee this ſecured▪ For Conſider,

1. Till your Sins are forgiven, they are imputed. All the Sin, the Guilt whereof derives to any of the Children of men, ſtands out againſt them, till a pardon removes it, by taking away the Imputation: his whole account abides on record, and is not croſſed.

2. Your danger by this is very great. You cannot anſwer the Juſtice of God for one of theſe Sins, and what an innumerable Company of them is there? So that you go in continual hazard of being laid up by Juſtice, and proſecuted for them, and then what a woful condition are you in? Our Saviour therefore adviſeth, Luk. 12.48, 49.

3. When once you are pardoned, there is no more imputation, that paſſeth off with it. As God ſeeth no Sin, ſo he will charge none: he faith of every one whom he forgiveth, that none of his Iniquities ſhall be remembered againſt him.

4. Hence now you may look upon your ſelves, yea, your ſins, without dread. This takes away the ground of terrours, becauſe it blots out the Hand writing that was againſt you. If, when the Books are opened, there is nothing there to be ſeen, but it hath the lines of Chriſt's Blood croſſing it, or his Satisfaction and Payment charged
on the other ſide, all is ſafe and well. And for help, remember,
1. Your ſins muſt be imputed ſome where. The Juſtice of God requires this.
2. Jeſus Chriſt hath enough in his Satisfaction to anſwer for them, and ſo to remove the Imputation to his ſcore: there is nothing wanting in his Righteouſneſs to anſwer all.

3. He offers it to you to be made yours. This is the deſign of the Goſpel treaty, to propoſe Chriſt to Sinners; and that is one thing in it, to be their Righteouſneſs, 1 Cor 1.30 And what is this for, but that he may diſcharge the Debt or Imputation for them?

4. If you would have it, you muſt go to Chriſt, and believe in him for it. It comes in by believing; and Chriſt is the author of that faith, it muſt be fetched from him; none but Believers can ſhare in this Imputation of his Obedience. Come then to him, wait on him, ſeek him to cure you of your Unbelief, and give you faith.

5. And you muſt renounce all your other dependencies. If you rely on a righteouſneſs of your own, that will never • o; Juſtice is not ſatisfyed with it; it cannot anſwer the Law for you. Come then with your ſins, and confeſs your inſufficiency, addreſs free grace, put up that petition, Psal 25.11. For thy name ſake, Oh Lord, pardon mine iniquity, ſo ſhall the Imputation of Sin, ceaſe, and you be made bleſſed.

div.head: A Pardoned Man is one without Guile. DOCTRINE VI.
div.p:
THE Pardoned Man is one in whoſe Spirit there is no Guile. It was obſerved in opening of the Text, that theſe laſt words of it, are put for the evidence of ſuch a perſon, whoſe happineſs is deſcribed from his pardoned ſtate: or a Characteriſtical note by which a man may know himſelf to be ſuch an one. Pardon of ſin, in a Theological ſenſe, properly refers to the great benefit of Justification: for though, among men it is one thing to Juſtifie a perſon, and another thing to pardon him: a man is then only Juſtified at a Civil Bar, when he is legally found innocent, or not Guilty of the Crime he was Indicted for; whereas a pardon ſuppoſeth the man to have been found Guilty, and a Sentence accordingly to have paſt upon him to ſuffer according to the Law; and then the ſupream power doth, upon prerogative, acquit • him from the Sentence, and ſet him at liberty, without any ſatisfaction given for the Crime: whereas God, in pardoning the Sinner, looks upon him in his Surety, at whoſe hands his Juſtice hath received Satisfaction, and accordingly acquits him Judicially, as, 2 Cor. 5.21. And ſo the Juſtice, as well as the Mercy of God doth herein diſplay it ſelf, 1 Ioh. 1.9. It is true, if we look upon the man in
himſelf, and with reference to the Covenant of Works, ſo it is a pardon; for the Law hath found him Guilty, and condemned him. Such is the condition of every one in his natural ſtate; and in that regard there is an act of free forgiveneſs paſſeth upon him, who hath done nothing himſelf to obtain it, and ſo the wonderful grace of God herein appears. But look upon him in Chriſt, as he w ••
•• dented for in the Covenant of Redemption, and is p •• in • o him under the Covenant of Grace, ſo the ſatisfactory Obedience of Chriſt is reputed as his, and on this trial he is found without iniquity, i. e Imputatively; and hereupon is acquitted: and that is a Juſtification, and belongs to it as one eſſential part of it: and ſo is that to be underſtood, Numb. 23 21. Now, though there be a wonderful change of ſtate that paſſeth upon the man in Juſtification; for in it he paſſeth from Condemnation, and is adjudged to an Eternal Kingdom; yet, becauſe it is meerly Relative, it hath not in it fell a ſelf-evidence, but muſt be diſcovered ſome other way; and becauſe it doth not paſs upon all men, ſince the greater pa • t of mankind will 〈◊〉 under Condemnation: Nor indeed are the 〈◊〉 Juſtified as Elected, but when the New Cove •••• is ratified with them; nor can they kn • w their Election till they can diſcern their Juſtification; it therefore concerns every one to be inquiſitive after this; and becauſe it is not made known by Immediate Revelation, but by concomitan •
Effects, enquiry is to be made after them; and therefore we have one of them laid before us
in our Text and Doctrine. Here then three things may be enquired into;
1. What is to be underſtood by one in whoſe Spirit there is no Guile?
2. Whether this have any influence into our pardon or Justification?
3. What evidence this gives to confirm us in the knowledge and belief of our being pardoned and juſtified? Of theſe in order.
1. What is to be underſtood by one in whoſe Spirit there is no Guile?

A. This manner of expreſſion is uſed in the Scriptures more than once, as a Periphraſis of a Godly man: So, Joh. 1.47 Rev. 14 5. The word [Guile] ſignifies Fraud or Deceit; but is uſed equivocally, Sometimes in a good, ſometimes in a bad ſenſe. There is an honeſt Craft, 2 Cor. 12.16. and there is a diſhoneſt one, which is pointed at in our Text: and there are many things in which this Guile is practiſed; there is Guile in mens words, ſuch is Flattery, Pſal 12.2, 3 and Lying to deceive, Mic. 6.12. And there is Guile in mens carriages, when they pretend Friendſhip, and yet lye in wait, Pſal. 55.21. And there is Guile in a Profeſſion of Religion, 2 Tim. 3.5. But the root of all this lies at the heart, the falſeneſs whereof puts men upon theſe Guileful practiſes: Hence Guile is in the word of God uſed for Hypocriſy; and to be without Guile for Sincerity: And when this is referred to the Spirit or Soul, it intends that there is an inward principle of it in the man which influenceth into his
Life and Converſation; and this points us to that Sanctification that is wrought in the man at Converſion. But for a more particular opening of this, obſerve theſe things

1. That in the beſt of Gods Children here, there is a Body of Death remaining. We have Paul himſelf crying out by reaſon of it, Rom. 7.24. And what elſe is intended by this, but the relicks or rem • ins of the Sinful Corruption, which the nature of man is defiled with by the Apoſtaſy? It is that Sinfulneſs in our nature, which hath in it a repugnancy to the Law of God, and cannot yield ſubjection to it, Rom. 8.7. And therefore is always Warning againſt the Law in the Mind, Chap. 7.23. And for any meer man, in this Life, to exempt himſelf from it, is counted a daring piece of impudence, Prov. 20 9. Hence that Hypotheſis, 1 Joh. 1.8. If we ſay we have no Sin, we deceive our ſelves: And that poſitive Concluſion, Eccl. 7.20. There is not a juſt man upon earth, that doeth good, and ſinneth not.

2. That in this Body of Death, there is a remaining Sinful Guile. It is therefore called a Body, becauſe there is every branch or member of carnal Concupiſcence in it: for, though the whole of it be mortifyed in Sanctification, yet there is no member of it is wholly deſtroyed, but remains, though not in its reigning power; and there is no luſt but a Child of God ſhall find the ſtirring of it in him, if he wa • ily obſerve himſelf. Now this Guile is one of thoſe Luſts, or rather a quality of them all; and all men bring it with them into the
World, riveted to their co • rupt nature, Pſal. 58. 4. On which account we have that aſſertion of the Prophet, Jer. 17 9. The Heart is deceitful above all things.

3. That this Guile doth too often wofully break forth in the Lives of Gods people. And this is a ſufficient evidence that it is there, for if they had none, they would never diſcover any: but how often doth it appear to others? And though it many times acts cloſely and indiſcernibly to the world, yet they themſelves might obſerve it, if they would be acquainted at home▪ Do not good men ſometimes act deceitfully in their treating with others? Did not David wofully lye and diſſemble to Ahimelech at Nob? 1 Sam. 21. And to Achiſh, Chap. 23. Yea he was almoſt gotten into a way of it, whence he prayes againſt it, Pſal. 119 29. And how much of Hypocriſy is a ſenſible Believer acquainted with in himſelf, attending on his beſt duties? How many wry glances, and ſiniſter aims in his prayers, and hearing, and whole Converſation? Whence elſe is it that he is ſo often at a loſs what to judge of himſelf as to any thing he doth?

4. In the work of Converſion there is a new nature put into the man. The man that is here ſaid to be without Guile, is to be ſuppoſed a true Convert, for there is nothing elſe but Guile in an Unconverted man; he is wholly acted by a Deceived Heart which perverts him. Iſa. 44 20. But when God comes to Convert a Sinner to himſelf, he then makes a powerful and thorough Change in him, 2 Cor. 5.17. This is that which is called
the New Man, in oppoſition to natural Corruption, which is called the Old man, Eph. 4.22, 24. This is called the New Heart, which God hath ſaid he will give to men in this work, Ezek 36 26. And what elſe is the New Nature, but a body of Sanctifying Graces, infuſed into the man, by which he is Regenerated, or born again?

5. In this new nature there is no Guile at all. The new Creature is altogether void of Sinful Hypocriſy, it hath nothing in it but what is pure, and ſincere, and without Guile. We read, 1 Joh. 3.9. Whoſoever is born of God doth not commit ſin. i. e. According to his new nature, or the new principle that is infuſed into him: and it muſt need appear to be ſincere, and not Hypocritical, from the Conſideration of the Original of it, and that is from God; it is therefore ſaid to be
〈◊〉 of him, 1 Joh. 5.4. And Born from above, Joh.
• .3. And of the Spirit, Verſ. 6. And is called the Divine Nature, 2 Pet 1.4. It never conſents to▪ much leſs contrives any deceit or cheat, but is always upright in the exertings of it ſelf. And therefore every Converted man, ſo far as he is renewed, ſo far is he altogether without Guile. As Guile is a quality adhering to every Luſt, ſo integrity is no leſs to every Grace of the Spirit, that is in the Children of God: their Faith is Unfeigned, 1 Tim. 1.5. And their Love is without Diſſimulation, Rom. 12.9. And ſuch are all the Graces which flow from theſe two, which are the root Graces in a Child of God.

6. The New Nature ſets it ſelf againſt the Guile of the Law in the members, in a Child of God. It
doth not only exert none it ſelf, nor conſent to that which the Corrupt part is acting, but it diſſents from, and withſtands it. There is the Luſting of the Spirit mentioned, Gal. 5.17. And there are two things wherein it diſcovers this.

1. In the Reluctancy of it againſt the Corrupt part in us, ſeeking to ſuppreſs and prevent it. So far as Grace is active in the heart of a Child of God, when it meets with a Temptation to Guile or Hypocriſy, it Reſiſts it, bears its Teſtimony againſt it; influenceth the Conſcience according to its preſent activity, ſo as to endeavour to Arm it againſt that part in him, which is eager and violent for it: and this Paul deſigns in, Rom. 7. When he ſpeaks of the Good he would do, and the Evil he would not do. And doubtleſs, many a time, by the help of the Spirit of God, he gets the Victory, overcomes the Temptation, and rejects the Motion with abhorrence.

2. In the Repentance which it brings the man to afterwards. Sometimes the Law of the Members is too ſubtile and ſtrong, and leads the man Captive, and he is drawn into Diſſimulation, as Peter and Barnabas were, Gal. 2.12. &c. The deceitfulneſs of his worſer part impoſeth upon him, and he plays the Fool; but as his Grace had no hand in it, but was meerly overborn; ſo it recruits again, and what it could not prevent by withſtanding, it clears it ſelf of, by Repentance. The Godly ſorrow, bitter mourning, ſelf-abhorrence and mortification he applies to it, witneſſeth for him, 2 Cor. 7.11. And this belongs to that Spiritual warfare, with which the Goſpel acquaints us.

7. That God, in the New-Covenant, values 〈◊〉 according to this New Nature. It is true, the Corruption within us, is Originally our own, and we have reaſon to bewail it as long as we Live; and it gives the Believer a world of grief and moleſtation. And when we neglect our Graces, and allow or nouriſh our Corruptions, God, as a Father, is angry, and Corrects us for it: but however, God looks upon his People according to their Grace. This is the New-Creature, and they are judged ſuch who have it in them. And where there 〈◊〉 this warfare againſt Corruption, and Grace exerciſed in Reſiſtance and Repentance, God is pleaſe • to accept of us; and though he Charge the other upon our Concupiſcence, and will Mortify it 〈◊〉 us, yet he Chargeth it not ſo upon the perſon, 〈◊〉 to put him out of his Favour for it. And on this account it is, that Paul dares to put it off from himſelf to his Sin, Rom. 7.16▪ 17.
8. Hence ſuch an one is, in a Goſpel eſteem, one in whom is no Guile. Who,

1. Hath been Regenerated by the Spirit of God, and ſo hath a principle of ſaving Grace in him. A Godly man, and one without Guile ſound the ſame thing in Scripture language: he is therefore ſo called, Context, verſe 6. for by vertue of ſuch a ſaving change, the man comes to have a Right Spirit in him, as it called, Pſal. 51.10.

2. Hereupon he cordially and ſincerely propounds the Glory of God as his laſt end, in his whole courſe. Though he may miſs it in the application in many things, yet this is the general
ſcope of his life, and he ſtudieth it daily; this is the great concern that lies upon him, 1 Cor. 10.3. And this is the natural inclination of the new nature in us: for it was put into us to enable us to Glorify God, and hath therefore in it a tendency to the end it was Created for, and accordingly prompts us hereunto.

3. Hence he abhors every thing in him that draws to the contrary. He finds enough and too much in himſelf which is moleſting of him, and ſometimes wofully too hard for him; but he is grieved at it, carries it about as his burden, and cries out by reaſon of it; yea he is vile in his own eyes on this account, as he, Job 41.5. accounts it his miſery, that he is ſo unhappily chained to it.

4. Hereupon he lives in the practice of the mortification of this deceitfulneſs. As he doth not allow it, ſo he cannot be quiet for it, but ſeeks to have it deſtroyed. We are commanded to mortify the luſts in us, Col. 3.5. and he makes it his buſineſs to do ſo, he fights againſt it, he brings it to the Croſs of Chriſt to be crucified, he prays hard againſt it, Pſal. 119.29. he hates it, v. 128. Such an one, in Gods gracious account is one in whoſe Spirit is no Guile.
2. Whether this have any influence into our pardon, Justification?

A. There is occaſion to make this enquiry here, becauſe the diſputes about it, which began from the firſt planting of the Churches by the Apoſtles,
are not yet at an end; nor do Papiſts only continue to maintain their Doctrine of merit, and th • confounding of Juſtification with Sanctification; but there are others, who call themſelves Protestants, and are not willing to be counted Arminia ••
neither; who go about to depreciate the free Grace of God in pardoning and juſtifying of us▪ who, whiles they aſcribe all to Chriſt as the meritorious cauſe, yet find the matter of our Juſtification in us, which they would have to be our Sanctification, and New-Obedience, our faith and Repentance, and Holineſs: and they make theſe not only neceſſarily concomitant, but an eſſential part of our Juſtification. Give me leave then to clear up this matter, and ſhew the miſtake of ſuch an opinion in the following Concluſions.

1. That Juſtification and Sanctification are two diſtinct benefits flowing to us from Chriſt. However vain men have confounded them, yet the Scripture ſpeaks of them as divers priviledges one from the other, ſo 1 Cor. 1.30. Chriſt indeed is made both Righteouſneſs and Sanctification to us, but they are two things▪ and applied to us after a different manner. We are Juſtified relatively; we are Sanctified really; we are Juſtified by Imputation, we are Sanctified by Infuſion; Juſtification is a Garment thrown over us, Sanctification is by a new principle put into us; Juſtification is a Change in our ſtate, Sanctification is a Change in our nature; in the one we are made legally innocent, in the other we are made inherently holy; hence the o • e is ſaid to be an Act, and the other is called a Work
by our Divines: becauſe the one paſſeth upon us Declaratively; whereas the other operates in us Effectually.

2. That both of theſe derive to us from the ſame fountain of free grace. Mans whole Salvation doth ſo, Eph. 2.8. and both of theſe do appertain to it; that Juſtification is a fruit of meer Grace, we are plainly aſſured, Rom. 3.24. And hence pardon is to be ſought of God, or for his own name ſake, Psal. 25.11. And our Sanctification hath the ſame original too, for it is a product of his meer good pleaſure, Jam. 1.18. Grace therefore, which is the ſame thing, is given of God, Pſal. 84.11. God ows neither of them to us, we • ave no way obliged him to beſtow them upon us rather than others. We have nothing but Sin, and Guilt, and pollution cleaving to us in our natural ſtate, when God comes to pardon and purifie us; quickning is beſtowed on them that were the Children of wrath, Eph. 2.1, 3. How then ſhould our Sanctification, or being without Guile, poſſibly contribute any thing to our Juſtification or Pardon?

3. That they are both of them applied together in or upon our Effectual Vocation. They are contemporaries: for though Divines do allow them an order in the handling of them, and an order of nature, and accordingly give the priority to Juſtification; yet there is no diſtance of time between the one and the other, by their acknowledgment; and they are reckoned as benefits joyntly flowing from our Effectual Calling;
and indeed it is in Regeneration, that we pa •• from death to life; there it is that we are quickned; and there is a double life that we paſs to, according to the double death that paſt upon us: we were dead in the Law, by the Condemnation denounced on us, but now we are made to live by a pardon, in which we are Juſtified; and we were dead in treſpaſſes and ſins, ſpiritually, and now we are made to live to Holineſs by a new inſpiration; and if we are no ſooner Sanctified than Juſtified, how can our Sanctification afford any matter for our Juſtification?

4. That becauſe pardon belongs to Juſtification, hence it muſt needs have a reſpect to a Righteouſneſs from whence 〈◊〉 proceeds▪ We have already taken notice of the difference between mens pardoning a Criminal, and Gods forgiving a Sinner: their pardon is not a Juſtification, 〈…〉 , theirs proceeds from 〈◊〉 mercy, his fro • mercy tempered with Juſtice; theirs is entirely prerogative, but his hath a reſpect to a Law to which he muſt be juſt in it, Rom. 3.26. and this refers not to his Soveraign Justice barely, which is nothing elſe but his Supremacy, but his Relative Juſtice, as he is Law giver, and hath conſtituted a way of procedure with his Creature. In this therefore there muſt be a Righteouſneſs regarded by him, to which he hath an eye in the very pardoning of the Sinner, and that Righteouſneſs muſt be ſuch as will anſwer it, ſo that mercy and truth may meet together, &c. Pſal. 85.10.

5. That this Righteouſneſs can be no other but
that perfect Righteouſneſs which was required in the Covenant of Works. God did in the Firſt Covenant, that was made with man in our firſt Parents, conſtitute the Rule of Righteouſneſs between him and man; and to that Rule it was that the promiſes and threatnings were annexed; and hence the procedure of Gods Relative Juſtice with man, muſt be according to the tenour of that; when therefore God comes to pardon and juſtifie a Sinner, that is the Righteouſneſs he proceeds upon: the queſtion is, may this be done, and the honour of the Law be ſalv • d? and the reſolution of it is, that if there be a Righteouſneſs to be preſented for the perſon, that will fully anſwer the demand of the Law, and may be accepted as his, there will be no injury done to the Law; but if not, it will ſuffer by it. If it bate but a jot or tittle, it is ſo far a loſer, and for that reaſon our Saviour aſſures us that it ſhall not, Mat. 5.18.

6. That the moſt eminent ſincerity of the Children of God, doth not amount to ſuch a Righteouſneſs. And if this be ſo, here is reaſon enough to deny it to be the meritorious or material cauſe of pardon and Juſtification; for, if it were perfect, it could not merit for us a pardon, becauſe we owe it: but if it be imperfect, it cannot be reputed a Righteouſneſs at all, with reſpect to the Law-Covenant. It is certain, that the Righteouſneſs which that required was ſuch as is without the leaſt flaw or defect, and we ſee how ſtraitly man was obliged, if he hoped to Eſcape the Curſe of it, Gal. 3.10. One
failure ſpoils it, and makes it become Unrighteouſneſs. Now all our Sanctification at preſent is imperfect, and hath mixtures of Sinful defilement adhering to it. It is a Ragged thing, Iſa. 64. 6. Jam. 3 2 When we are moſt without Guile, there is a mixture of Guile; ſo that the holieſt of men have dreaded, and deprecated a rigorous Law procedure with them, as knowing that they could not ſtand it, Pſal. 130.3. & 143.2. It is an act of Gods rich Grace to accept of the beſt and moſt ſincere duties that we do; and if there were not a Chriſt in whom they are accepted, it would not be: there is a pardon that muſt be continued and applyed to them, elſe we had no hope: the Defilement of the Holy things of Gods Iſrael muſt be expiated.

7 That the Righteouſneſs of Chriſt doth alone anſwer this. This doth, and none elſe can: this is the Righteouſneſs of God, viz. of Gods providing and of him who was God; it was perfect in it ſelf, it anſwered all the Laws demands, it complied with both the Sanctions of it, it gave the Juſtice of God the greateſt ſatisfaction that could be: he did all that the Law required, and ſuffered all which that threatned in caſe of ſin: it was ſuch a righteouſneſs as no other but the Son of God in our nature could offer; and hence our pardon can be influenced by no other but this, nor can the matter of our Juſtification be any thing elſe, becauſe nothing elſe can ſtand for 〈◊〉
▪

8. That the Commendation and Reward which
Chriſt will give to the Holineſs of his people at the Great Day, belongs not to their Juſtification, but their Glorification. There will be ſuch a thing, Math. 25.34. &c. But all this is done after their Juſtification, and when they are in a ſtate of Grace and Favour, and under the priviledges and promiſes of the New Covenant. Now, in that New Covenant, although there be no worthineſs in us, and all our duties are but our duty, and we Unprofitable, Luk. 17.10 Yet our Father who by his Spirit worketh our works in us, and giveth us the Grace to Live without Guile, and to Serve him in uprightneſs of Heart, accepts of his own works in us, gives us the Commendation of them, and beſtows a reward upon us, to let us know, that our labour hath not been in vain; yet it is not a reward of Debt, but of Grace. Hence that obſervable difference, Rom. 6.23. The wages of Sin is Death, but the gift of God is Eternal Life, through Jeſus Chriſt our Lord: But this and ſuch like Scriptures are abuſively applyed to our Juſtification: for that proceeds according to the Rule ſet down by God in his Law, being anſwered by a Surety for us; whereas Glorification is another thing, and is beſtowed on ſuch as were before Pardoned and Sanctified, and made meet for the inheritance, Rom. 8.30.
3. What evidence our being without Guile giveth, to confirm us in the belief and knowledge of our being Pardoned or Juſtifyed?

A. That Juſtification and Sanctification are joynt benefits flowing from Effectual Vocation,
